channel.title: Finishing My Music
channel.description:
Over the years, I've written hundreds of jams in Auxy, Logic Pro X, Garageband for iOS, and a few other places. I say "written" because, with a few exceptions, NOT A SINGLE ONE of them is finished. And in order for me to make any progress in the musical world, that has got to end soon.
Here's my theory on why this is the case: I sit down, possibly with nothing in my head, perhaps with a fully formed track in there. I start writing, recording, editing, etc, and soon I've got the beginnings of a drop. Once I think I've mostly finished the drop, I start to write a lead in to my drop. I flesh that out as I see fit. Now, I'm left with a 1:30 or so jam... ...and I don't know where to go.
Any advice?
I know there are tons of ways to structure tracks (e.g.: A-B-A type movements, Chorus/Verse/Bridge type sections, etc.) My problem is, once I've climbed all the way up to that Chorus/Climax/Drop, I am at a loss as to where to go. Should I introduce new musical material, or should I go with a more repitition-based approach? I have a lot of trouble avoiding being "too repetitive", and not introducing so much new material that it becomes a whole different song.
In addition, what are the elements of a song you don't repeat? Transitions? Buildups? Melodies? Basslines?
Oh my...I've got so many questions...I hope they make sense and aren't too much to answer... I know that "practice makes perfect." The problem is, I don't know what to practice!
With regard to the wonderful Auxy community, Help! :exploding_head:

item.title: Finishing My Music
item.dc:creator: moemx
item.description:
Dope questions. I think arrangement / structure is the major task that can help so much to get your track rolling.

I‚Äôd consider either a) a regular/stringent buildup from 0 to 100 if you‚Äôre working with a genre that allows that (like ambient, downtempo, piano stuff and epic things), or b) a rather classical arranged structure if more pop/tech oriented:

  • intro
  • 1st buildup/drop
  • 1st chorus
  • post-chorus
  • ‚Äòverse‚Äô if you wanna call it that way (maybe introducing a new melody/ addition
  • 2nd buildup/drop
  • 2nd chorus
  • outro

That - at least- works its magic for me most of the times but also: really feel free to dm so many of us for feedback on specific songs (which we all should do more). <3

item.title: Finishing My Music
item.dc:creator: Alyen
item.description:
I would go with the more repetitive approach after the drop to keep it familiar, but make variations to avoid tiring repetition. You could also change it into a different track altogether, then later bring it back to the original idea.

Perhaps the thought that there is a right or wrong way of structuring, is what‚Äôs slowing down creative momentum. IMO, there are no wrong ways of doing things, just ‚Äúbetter‚Äù ways and common ways.

item.title: Finishing My Music
item.dc:creator: BobTheGUYYYYY
item.description:
Generally, I‚Äôll lay down a melody, build, drop, transition back into the melody, build, drop again, transition back into a little melody chorus before I end the song. You could do that too, or write a slightly different drop of the two. Your choice. And hey, if you have two UNFINISHED songs, why not try putting them together to get one ‚Äúfinished‚Äù song? Worth a try‚Ä¶!
